lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, components can have children, which can be passed as props. This allows us to create complex UIs by nesting components.

Let's learn how to pass children to components step-by-step.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
So far, we've learned that a component in React is written like a self-closing HTML tag.

That's true for components that don't have children.

Make sure to pick < followed by Header and then /, >.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To pass children to a component, we wrap content between its opening and closing tags.

Pass the text Less is more. as the child of Quote.

Make sure to pick <Quote>, followed by Less is more., and finally </Quote>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Next, let's see how we can access the children passed to a component. React provides the children prop for easily accessing this content.

Display the children of the Quote component inside an embedded expression.

Make sure to pick { followed by props and then ., children, }.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
An alternative to passing content as children is to pass it as a regular property.

Pass the text "Less is more." as the property content to the Quote component.

Make sure to pick content, followed by =, and finally "Less is more.".

lessons.title: b
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we want to render nested content, passing it as children has a few advantages over passing it as regular properties.

In React, children is a convention for passing inner content, making it easier to understand its purpose.

Make sure to pick <Quote>, followed by Less is more., and finally </Quote>.

lessons.title: b - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In addition, with children, we can easily nest more complex elements inside a parent element if needed.

Pass content with an emphasis on the word less as a child to the Quote component.

Make sure to pick <em> followed by Less and then </em>, is more..

lessons.title: b - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Remember, components are like building blocks of our React app. This approach allows us to pass multiple components as children.

Complete the code to pass CardHeader, CardBody, and CardFooter all as children to the Card component.

Make sure to pick <Card>, followed by </Card>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We don't have to use other components as children. As we've seen before, we can also just pass text as the child.

Pass the simple text Act without expectation. as the child of Quote.

Make sure to pick <Quote>, followed by Act without expectation., and finally </Quote>.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component named Footnote that accepts children and renders them italicized.

Make sure to pick props followed by { and then props, ., children, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be displayed when the Banner component is rendered?

Welcome to the Jungle!{props.children}BannerAn error

Welcome to the Jungle!.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component named Highlight that uses children to display a highlighted message.

Make sure to pick Highlight followed by props and then return, <mark>, {props.children}, </mark>.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the output of the following React app?

A paragraph wrapped with a borderA paragraph highlightedA syntax errorA heading wrapped with a border

A paragraph wrapped with a border.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component named Alert that accepts text as children and displays them.

Make sure to type children.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement is true about the children prop?

It allows components to render nested contentIt is used only for passing textIt is a method to pass propertiesIt disallows components from being nested

It allows components to render nested content.

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the Tip component to display a message.

Make sure to pick <Tip>, followed by Cool kids learn React!, and finally </Tip>.

lessons.title: Lesson #17
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do you pass children to the <Text> component?

<Text>Hello, world!</Text><Text children="Hello, world!" /><Text>{children: "Hello, world!"}</Text>We can't pass children to a component

<Text>Hello, world!</Text>.
